Award.AbstractNarration: Abstract<br/><br/>Award: DMS-0846408<br/>Principal Investigator: Anna Wienhard<br/><br/>The goal of the proposed project is to further develop the<br/>emerging field of higher Teichmueller theory. Higher Teichmueller<br/>spaces are connected components of the variety of representations<br/>of the fundamental group of a surface into semisimple Lie groups,<br/>which share essential properties with Teichmueller<br/>space. Classical Teichmueller space plays an important role in<br/>various fields of mathematics due to its rich structure and the<br/>fact that it is a smooth cover of the moduli space of Riemann<br/>surfaces. For higher Teichmueller spaces many potentially<br/>interesting structures are yet to be discovered and the relation<br/>to the moduli space of Riemann surfaces still needs to be<br/>clarified. The proposed research focusses on identifying the<br/>geometric objects (similar to hyperbolic surfaces in the case of<br/>classical Teichmueller space) which are parametrized by higher<br/>Teichmueller spaces. These objects will then be used to define<br/>algebraic, geometric and dynamical structures on higher<br/>Teichmueller spaces, and we expect that they will help to<br/>construct a natural map from higher Teichmueller spaces to<br/>classical Teichmueller space.<br/><br/>Teichmueller space is the space of all geometric surfaces with a<br/>fixed combinatorial type. Because it parametrizes all surfaces,<br/>Teichmueller space is a fundamental mathematical object which<br/>also plays an important role in theoretical physics. Every point<br/>in Teichmueller space corresponds to a tiling of the Euclidean<br/>plane, the two-dimensional sphere or in most cases the hyperbolic<br/>plane by one polygon and its images under subsequent reflections<br/>in the sides. (Nice pictures inspired by such tilings appear in<br/>M.C. Escher's work.) The combinatorial type of the surface is<br/>determined by the number of vertices of the polygon and the<br/>gluing data, but the geometry of the surface depends on the<br/>length of the sides and the angles at the vertices of the<br/>polygon. Teichmueller space is the example of a moduli space of a<br/>pattern (the tiling) with rich symmetries (the reflections in the<br/>side of the polygon). Such moduli spaces can be efficiently<br/>studied via the group generated by the symmetries of the<br/>pattern. Higher Teichmueller spaces are moduli spaces of more<br/>complicated patterns in higher dimensional spaces. However, the<br/>symmetry group of these patterns is the same as the symmetry<br/>group of the tilings associated to classical Teichmueller<br/>space. Therefore one expects higher Teichmueller spaces to<br/>parametrize geometric objects which are not surfaces themselves,<br/>but closely related to surfaces. The proposed research focusses<br/>on identifying these geometric objects and studying their finer<br/>structure.<br/><br/>The project proposes various activities to involve graduate<br/>students in research and teaching, as for instance a yearly<br/>mathematical retreat for graduate students to study, explore and<br/>present a mathematical topic in a group, and small workshops with<br/>mini-courses which allow graduate students to get insight into<br/>the working of modern research collaborations.<br/>
